title: Does an averagely armed militia stand a reasonable chance in resisting government tyranny? - Quora
tags: Gun Control in the United States of America

response.answer_text: No, it would not stand a chance, and the reasons are simple. First, if the uprising were that popular they wouldn’t need the uprising. If enough people joined the “militia” to make it a useful force, then figure: Relatively few people take up arms, so for everyone in the militia, there’s at least thousand not in it, and that’s just among the able-bodied. If the militia was big enough to accomplish anything, it’d have millions of supporters. At that point, they’d have enough representation to use the government to prevent tyranny, like everyone else has. Which means, if they had to resort to violent rebellion, they would not be very popular. And they’d lose much of that popularity quick if they do stupid things like taking away people’s electricity. The rebels would be quickly dehumanized in public perception and put down. Side note: American history is actually full of tyranny, but almost all of it was at the local level. Corrupt city machines, county “boss” systems, Jim Crow, governors declaring martial law against peaceful protests, or even sending national guard units to shoot at striking workers… lots of tyranny all through its history. Armed citizens almost never stood up to any of this, and in fact, they were on the side of the tyrants far more often. In a case like this, you’d probably see groups of pro-government citizens fighting the rebellious ones. But let’s say some rebels started an insurgency against tyranny for once. They’d get squashed by military forces, if law-and-order weren’t up to the task. People like to talk about how the US army got “beaten” by insurgents in far-off foreign lands. It’s a different story closer to home. For every person who says that soldiers won’t shoot at Americans… if the Americans shoot at them first, they sure as hell will shoot back. Cops have no problems with it when their lives are on the line. Besides, how many Americans are willing to plant a car bomb and blow up a supermarket? A hospital? A school? A church? That’s what insurgents in these places do. Why? Because they’re fighting each other as much as they’re fighting us. There are lots of different sides each vying for control. They fight us because we’re there trying to help one side win. Our success depends on the quality of the side we’re helping, and let’s face it, if they had been strong enough to be worth helping, they wouldn’t need our help. In comparison, a unified rebellion movement would be much easier to keep under wraps, even if you didn’t wipe it out completely. And the US would be fighting for itself, supported by its solid, stable system of government, not trying to prop up a cut-rate potentate weakened by the birthing pangs of inexperience and corruption. A better comparison than Iraq or Afghanistan would be Ireland during the troubles, or the Basque groups during and after Franco. These areas had rebellious militia/terrorist groups who fought tough and brutal fights for decades, and they began as responses to tyranny, and had a lot of popular support. Neither accomplished their goals (unification or independence), and to be honest, they never even came close. And they had bombs. High explosives. Sure, American insurgents could get their hands on some, if they’re willing to use them. But without more advanced weaponry they’re toast. Personal firearms are nice, but without heavy weaponry you’ll always be facing a losing battle against the US Army on territory it wants. Just ask the Indians. Dozens of nations fought insurgencies for decades, but eventually the US Army beat them all, by means fair and foul, because it was fighting for itself and on territory it considered its own.

You’re really asking two different questions here. To the first (and main) question: Yes it does. Look at what illiterate people living in mud huts in Afghanistan managed to do. A coalition of multiple countries was not able to maintain control over that country. The US is much bigger than Afghanistan, and our people generally are better educated, have greater access to information, and have access to more resources. An insurgency isn’t about taking the enemy head-on. You don’t need to shoot down fighter jets. You stay hidden or mobile. You strike fast at a soft target and then disappear. If a tank is rolling down the street and you have no weapons to defeat it, you kick back at home and let it roll on by. When that convoy of mechanized infantry rolls down the road on patrol, you let it roll by. When that convoy of logistics trucks comes down the road, you hit them hard. Insurgencies aren’t a matter of a few battles. They are about political will. You create a situation where it is more advantageous for the government to give into your demands than to keep the conflict going. Or you keep gaining more and more support from the people and foreign partners until you truly become a force to be reckoned with. Also, tyranny doesn’t always have to come from the federal government. Take the Battle of Athens for example. A militia formed to oust a corrupt local government. Early efforts to unionize pitted union workers against hired thugs from certain large companies, some of which basically were the government in a given town. At least one of those, the Battle of Blair Mountain, escalated until the US Army got involved. While the battle itself was technically a loss (and led to other short-term losses), it helped draw attention to conditions the workers faced, and ultimately helped gain support nationally. Even the case of the Bundy Ranch can serve as an example here. Now ignore the specific circumstance that led up to this, as this is a controversial example that many people would not actually consider to be a case of government tyranny. However, a group of armed people (some might call them a militia) showed up and the government stood down. Does it matter that they didn’t overthrow the government? Not really, the question asked if they could “resist” tyranny, and while it may not have been tyranny, they resisted something. Does it matter that it wasn’t a battle won with sweat, blood, and bullets? Nope. Does it matter than the government could have killed every last one of those civilians if it really wanted to? Nope. Everyone has limits. Part of a successful insurgency is knowing your enemy’s limits and exploiting them. Now to your questions about the specific comments you linked to: That guy is an idiot. I doubt he ever worked for the military at all much less in that specific capacity. So 75% of the military will desert in a Civil War? That’s interesting. Did you know that 60% of all statistics are made up on the spot? The last Civil War didn’t see a 75% desertion rate, nor have any other government actions.

That document is not meant to be accurate, it’s meant to be propaganda. I’m not saying that a popular uprising could not succeed in the US under the correct conditions, but consider the facts: Any rebellion would be horribly outgunned, even considering simple conventional weapons. And by ‘horribly’ I mean rifles and perhaps the odd 50 caliber machine gun against modern armor, cruise missiles, advanced fighter jets, and even drones. Even with the (extremely unlikely) cited 50–75% desertion rate the blurb cites, a rebellion would need huge popular support simply to offset the mind-boggling casualty rates they would suffer.The kind of people who are likely to lead and participate in a popular rebellion of this sort do not have the organization or tools they would need to control areas that they might manage to ‘liberate’. They would quickly run into organized resistance from citizens who oppose their coup attempt, and while those citizens would be less skilled, they would not have had their numbers decimated by the initial combat with the US military, and would quickly overwhelm rebels in many areas.While it’s true that civilian populations in urban areas might suffer, the US military itself has stockpiles of food and munitions, much better mobility, and people trained in long-term strategy. They would retreat, regroup, and then use their overwhelming force to take the country back one ill-defended region at a time. Citizens would die, yes, but that’s a feature of war.The best-case scenario (from the rebel’s perspective) would be something like the current status of ISIL: partial control over an ill-defined and constantly shifting territory, defended by largely independent teams of men with pickup trucks and long guns, with no economy and no capacity for producing new armaments on their own. Worst case, it would all break down into small, isolated groups of militants running guerrilla campaigns, and being slowly picked off. It would be ugly, brutal, and ultimately hopeless. It might be a different matter if actual states tried to secede (as in the original civil war); states have organizational capacity and governmental infrastructure of their own; they have the tools to organize a coherent military campaign. But seceding states would not allow the kind of random, anarchical ‘popular’ revolution the blurb talks about. They would induct people into service and train and equip them properly. But the surest sign that this is impossible is the fact that someone published it. If anyone really thought this was a viable proposal they would take extreme measures to make sure it was kept quiet; no one seriously planning a military coup broadcasts their strategy for everyone to read. Therefore, this is propaganda meant to stir up the faithful to some other action (like voting for Trump). Crazy talk so that crazy people have a chance to do some primal chest-thumping.

Look at Afghanistan and Iraq. The area of Afghanistan is 250,000 square miles. The area of Iraq is roughly 170,000 square miles. It was very hard to cover that much area with the forces that were sent there. Now look at the U.S. The area of the United States is around 3,800,000 square miles. That’s almost 4 million square miles. Can you imagine even a well-trained and well-equipped U.S. military covering an area that large? It would be a logistical nightmare. Plus add to the fact that probably half of the military would refuse to attack its own citizens over a matter in which they agreed with the rebellion. The military on the whole is slightly to the right of center and would likely side against the government. Many of those in the military would disregard the call to attack this country’s own citizens and take with them much of the equipment that had been assigned them and join the rebellion. Even with the increased military strength of the federal government, they would never win against the rebellion. They could do some damage, yes, but they could never, unless, I suppose, they decided to use nuclear weapons on their own soil. There are too many places where rebels could hide and from which to stage their attacks, especially west of the Mississippi. If the government declares war on its own citizens, good luck to them. Personally, I don’t think it will ever come to this, in part because the federal government knows they couldn’t win.

It depends on the funding the militia receives and how the tyrannical government responds to resistance. Armed militia with adequate funding (self funding or more frequently foreign government sponsorship) can resist government tyranny if the government doesn’t use ‘collective punishment’. However, if the government is willing to use significant collective punishment it changes the equation - if your family, neighbors and friends are likely to seriously suffer due to your actions - then it becomes much less effective. Without adequate funding it is easy for the militia to run out of ammunition, fuel and food. So Saddam could crush the rebels because there wasn’t any foreign funding and he was willing to engage in collective punishment. The US revolutionaries could win because we had French funding and the British weren’t willing to engage in collective punishment.

Insurgency is always about politics more than actual military issues. If there is an insurgency in the US, the person in that article correctly notes that it could easily lead to major desertion / rebellions within ranks if the insurgency has sufficient political momentum. Yes I’m sure the US military planners have thought about potential internal rebellion scenarios if only as due diligence

Rather than get bogged down in the sometimes silly and inflammatory statements made by those on both sides of this issue, why not ask and research a simple and direct question? To wit: how many times has a modern nation completely defeated an armed insurgency? Answer that and you'll likely have the answer to the question you asked here.

In a police state like Iran or Russia, no. In a modern democracy like America, Europe, Japan, Australia etc., no. In a failed state, no, because by definition the government is too weak to be tyrannical. Such states are always dominated by tyrannical militias, actually. So either a militia has no chance or it’s the tyrannical force. America has a population of 320 million or so people. Of that perhaps .1% believes in such malarky. The rest of us go about our lives.

Not an easy question to answer meaningfully with information provided. The answer is too complicated by situational exigencies. And resisting tyranny has les to do with being armed than being educated.
